chunks.chunk_text: This is a download from BBC Learning English. To find out more, visit our website.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json

chunks.chunk_text: People who use VR often describe the experience
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json

chunks.chunk_text: in whatever new world you've chosen. And it's this intensity that inventors, scientists and therapists are using to help people overcome their problems. We'll hear more soon, but first I have a question for you, Sam. One of the phobias VR can help with is the fear of heights. But what is the proper name for this psychological disorder?
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json

chunks.chunk_text: I'll say A. Electrophobia. OK, Sam. We'll find out the answer at the end of the programme. Now, if, like me, you're not very good with heights, you'll be happy to know that a company called Oxford VR has designed a system to help with precisely that problem. In the safety of your own home, you put on a headset and are guided through a series of tasks, moving you higher and higher off the ground. You start by taking an elevator
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json

chunks.chunk_text: to the top floor of tall buildings and move on to harder challenges like climbing a rope. Daniel Freeman is a professor of clinical psychology at Oxford University. Listen as he explains how the VR experience works to BBC World Service programme People Fixing the World.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Although the VR experience seems real, the person using it knows it's only a simulation – a pretend copy of the real thing. This gives them confidence to go higher, knowing they can't really get hurt.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Oxford VR's Fear of Heights experience uses VR to put people into another world. But the next project we'll hear about
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json

chunks.chunk_text: takes things even further – putting people into someone else's body.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Many of the prisoners lack empathy for their victims. Virtual embodiment works by giving these men the experience of abuse in the first person.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json

chunks.chunk_text: In VR, the men have the insults and abuse they gave to others turned back on them. It's a novel, a new and original experience for them – and not a pleasant one either. But the VR therapy seems to be working and Dr Sanchez-Vivez reports more and more of the prisoners successfully reintegrating into their communities after their release from prison.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json

chunks.chunk_text: I asked Sam whether the correct name for the Fear of Heights was electrophobia, arachnophobia or acrophobia. I guessed it was electrophobia. Which was the wrong answer. Electrophobia is the fear of chickens. The correct answer was C, acrophobia – a fear of heights and a good example of a fear of chickens.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Let's recap the rest of the vocabulary we've learned, starting with simulation – a pretend copy of something that looks real but is not. Habitual describes the usual, typical way something works. The phrase drop your defences means to relax and trust something by lowering your psychological barriers. In the first person means talking about something from the perspective of the person who actually experienced an event themselves.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json

chunks.chunk_text: The adjective novel means completely new and original, unlike anything that's happened before. Well, once again, our six minutes are really and virtually over. Goodbye for now. Bye.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Can VR treat fears and phobias_.json
